Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Neutron Monitor Observations of Cosmic Rays from Jang Bogo and McMurdo
Award.AbstractNarration: This award focuses on a specific research program that will be using data from the neutron monitor at McMurdo (which will be then moved to Jang Bogo) and from other worldwide locations. The research program is based on a unique southward cosmic rays "viewing direction" of the subject monitor for comprehensive analyses of individual solar events by measuring three dimensional distribution functions of solar energetic particles. The long and complete database acquired by the McMurdo monitor over 50+ years also plays an important role in the studies of historical trends in "solar modulation" of galactic cosmic rays and the influence of solar magnetic activity on the radiation input into the Earth's atmosphere. The recent deep solar minimum and slow recovery to the maximum are unprecedented for the potentially new era in the studies of the Sun. To ensure continuity of the McMurdo long-term dataset, it is proposed to move the monitor to the new Korean station Jang Bogo, which is located in Terra Nova Bay and has the viewing direction nearly identical to that of McMurdo. Solid science, international partners, and travel to Antarctica provide an ideal opportunity to achieve excellent education and outreach goals. By providing undergraduates and two-year college students with Antarctic research experience, the proposal demonstrates how a future generation of scientists can make meaningful contributions to the cutting-edge research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The neutron monitor at McMurdo station, established in 1960, was arguably the longest continuously running instrument at the station. The long and complete database acquired by the McMurdo monitor also plays an important role in studies of historical trends in “solar modulation”, or the influence of solar magnetic activity on cosmic ray fluxes and radiation input to the Earth’s atmosphere. The recent deep solar minimum and slow recovery to maximum are unprecedented for the era of accurate measurements by neutron monitors. This is a potentially new era in the study of the Sun. To ensure continuity of the dataset we moved the monitor to the new Korean station Jang Bogo that has a viewing direction nearly identical to that of McMurdo.

The two most significant papers supported in part by this award both had to do with the different behavior of solar modulation at low and high energies. In both cases, we used the McMurdo dataset as the standard reference for low energy data. Nuntiyakul et al. (2014) confirmed a curious linear relationship between fluxes of particles above different rigidity thresholds by detailed analysis of latitude survey data taken under previous NSF awards. The paper showed a highly systematic behavior in the energy dependence of the linear relationship, and showed that the slope of the relationship depended on solar magnetic polarity epoch. Mangeard et al. (2018) explored this relationship in detail by comparing data from the Princess Sirindhorn neutron monitor (PSNM) in Thailand to McMurdo data. This paper confirmed the general nature of the linear relationship; however, it also identified an interval several years long where the behavior was far more complex and documented solar wind conditions during both the simple and complex time intervals.

Undergraduate students participated extensively in the field operations surrounding the move, and documented their experiences via blogs hosted on the international science project IceCube web pages.

Nuntiyakul, W., P. Evenson, D. Ruffolo, A. Saiz, J. W. Bieber, J. Clem, R. Pyle, M. L. Duldig, and J. E. Humble (2014). Latitude Survey Investigation of Galactic Cosmic Ray Solar Modulation during 1994–2007.  The Astrophysical Journal. 795 (11), doi:10.1088/0004-637.

Mangeard, Pierre-Simon, John Clem, Paul Evenson, Roger Pyle, Warit Mitthumsiri, David Ruffolo, Alejandro Sáiz , and Tanin Nutaro (2018). Distinct Pattern of Solar Modulation of Galactic Cosmic Rays above a High Geomagnetic Cutoff Rigidity.  The Astrophysical Journal. 858 (43), DOI: https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aabd3c
